trans-unit.source: Set up protection between on-premises VMware virtual machines or physical servers and Azure
trans-unit.target: Set up protection between on-premises VMware virtual machines or physical servers and Azure

trans-unit.source: Describes up Azure Site Recovery to coordinate the replication, failover and recovery of on-premises VMware virtual machines or Windows/Linux physical servers to Azure.
trans-unit.target: Describes up Azure Site Recovery to coordinate the replication, failover and recovery of on-premises VMware virtual machines or Windows/Linux physical servers to Azure.

trans-unit.source: Set up protection between on-premises VMware virtual machines or physical servers and Azure
trans-unit.target: Set up protection between on-premises VMware virtual machines or physical servers and Azure

trans-unit.source: This article describes how to deploy Site Recovery to:
trans-unit.target: This article describes how to deploy Site Recovery to:

trans-unit.source: Protect VMware virtual machines—Coordinate replication, failover, and recovery of on-premises VMware virtual machines to Azure
trans-unit.target: Protect VMware virtual machines—Coordinate replication, failover, and recovery of on-premises VMware virtual machines to Azure

trans-unit.source: Protect physical servers—Coordinate replication, failover, and recovery of on-premises physical Windows and Linux servers to Azure using the Azure Site Recovery service.
trans-unit.target: Protect physical servers—Coordinate replication, failover, and recovery of on-premises physical Windows and Linux servers to Azure using the Azure Site Recovery service.

trans-unit.source: The article includes an overview, deployment prerequisites, and set up instructions.
trans-unit.target: The article includes an overview, deployment prerequisites, and set up instructions.

trans-unit.source: At the end of the article your VMware virtual machines or physical servers will be replicating to Azure.
trans-unit.target: At the end of the article your VMware virtual machines or physical servers will be replicating to Azure.

trans-unit.source: If you run into problems, post your questions on the <link><linkText>Azure Recovery Services Forum</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you run into problems, post your questions on the <link><linkText>Azure Recovery Services Forum</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: What is Azure Site Recovery?
trans-unit.target: What is Azure Site Recovery?

trans-unit.source: The Azure Site Recovery contributes to your business continuity and disaster recovery (BCDR) strategy by orchestrating replication, failover and recovery of virtual machines and physical servers.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Site Recovery contributes to your business continuity and disaster recovery (BCDR) strategy by orchestrating replication, failover and recovery of virtual machines and physical servers.

trans-unit.source: Machines can be replicated to Azure, or to a secondary on-premises data center.
trans-unit.target: Machines can be replicated to Azure, or to a secondary on-premises data center.

trans-unit.source: Read more about <link><linkText>Azure Site Recovery</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Read more about <link><linkText>Azure Site Recovery</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: How does it protect on-premises resources?
trans-unit.target: How does it protect on-premises resources?

trans-unit.source: Site Recovery helps protect your on-premises resources by orchestrating, simplifying replication, failover and failback in a number of <link><linkText>deployment scenarios</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Site Recovery helps protect your on-premises resources by orchestrating, simplifying replication, failover and failback in a number of <link><linkText>deployment scenarios</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: If you want to protect your on-premises VMware virtual machines or Windows or Linux physical servers here's how Site Recovery can help:
trans-unit.target: If you want to protect your on-premises VMware virtual machines or Windows or Linux physical servers here's how Site Recovery can help:

trans-unit.source: Allows VMware users to replicate virtual machines to Azure.
trans-unit.target: Allows VMware users to replicate virtual machines to Azure.

trans-unit.source: Allows the replication of physical on-premises servers to Azure.
trans-unit.target: Allows the replication of physical on-premises servers to Azure.

trans-unit.source: Provides a single location to setup and manage replication, failover, and recovery.
trans-unit.target: Provides a single location to setup and manage replication, failover, and recovery.

trans-unit.source: Provides easy failover from your on-premises infrastructure to Azure, and failback (restore) from Azure to on-premises.
trans-unit.target: Provides easy failover from your on-premises infrastructure to Azure, and failback (restore) from Azure to on-premises.

trans-unit.source: Implements recovery plans for easy failover of workloads that are tiered over multiple machines.
trans-unit.target: Implements recovery plans for easy failover of workloads that are tiered over multiple machines.

trans-unit.source: Provides multi VM consistency so that virtual machines and physical servers running specific workloads can be recovered together to a consistent data point.
trans-unit.target: Provides multi VM consistency so that virtual machines and physical servers running specific workloads can be recovered together to a consistent data point.

trans-unit.source: Supports data replication over the Internet, over a site-to-site VPN connection, or over Azure ExpressRoute.
trans-unit.target: Supports data replication over the Internet, over a site-to-site VPN connection, or over Azure ExpressRoute.

trans-unit.source: Provides automated discovery of VMware virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: Provides automated discovery of VMware virtual machines.

trans-unit.target: What do I need?

trans-unit.source: Deployment
trans-unit.target: Deployment

trans-unit.source: Details
trans-unit.target: Details

trans-unit.source: Configuration server
trans-unit.target: Configuration server

trans-unit.source: <html></html>Deploy as a Azure standard A3 virtual machine in the same subscription as Site Recovery.<html></html> <html></html>You set up in the Site Recovery portal<html></html>
trans-unit.target: <html></html>Deploy as a Azure standard A3 virtual machine in the same subscription as Site Recovery.<html></html> <html></html>You set up in the Site Recovery portal<html></html>

trans-unit.source: This server coordinates communication between protected machines, the process server, and master target servers in Azure.
trans-unit.target: This server coordinates communication between protected machines, the process server, and master target servers in Azure.

trans-unit.source: It sets up replication and coordinates recovery in Azure when failover occurs.
trans-unit.target: It sets up replication and coordinates recovery in Azure when failover occurs.

trans-unit.source: Master target server
trans-unit.target: Master target server

trans-unit.source: <html></html>Deploy as Azure virtual machine — Either a Windows server based on a Windows Server 2012 R2 gallery image (to protect Windows machines) or as a Linux server based on a OpenLogic CentOS 6.6 gallery image (to protect Linux machines).<html></html> <html></html>Three sizing options are available – Standard A4, Standard D14 and Standard DS4.<html></html><html></html>The server is connected to the same Azure network as the configuration server.<html></html><html></html>You set up in the Site Recovery portal<html></html>
trans-unit.target: <html></html>Deploy as Azure virtual machine — Either a Windows server based on a Windows Server 2012 R2 gallery image (to protect Windows machines) or as a Linux server based on a OpenLogic CentOS 6.6 gallery image (to protect Linux machines).<html></html> <html></html>Three sizing options are available – Standard A4, Standard D14 and Standard DS4.<html></html><html></html>The server is connected to the same Azure network as the configuration server.<html></html><html></html>You set up in the Site Recovery portal<html></html>

trans-unit.source: <html></html>It receives and retains replicated data from your protected machines using attached VHDs created on blob storage in your Azure storage account.<html></html> <html></html>Select Standard DS4 specifically for configuring protection for workloads requiring consistent high performance and low latency using Premium Storage Account.<html></html>
trans-unit.target: <html></html>It receives and retains replicated data from your protected machines using attached VHDs created on blob storage in your Azure storage account.<html></html> <html></html>Select Standard DS4 specifically for configuring protection for workloads requiring consistent high performance and low latency using Premium Storage Account.<html></html>

trans-unit.source: Process server
trans-unit.target: Process server

trans-unit.source: <html></html>Deploy as an on-premises virtual or physical server running Windows Server 2012 R2<html></html> <html></html>We recommend it's placed on the same network and LAN segment as the machines that you want to protect, but it can run on a different network as long as protected machines have L3 network visibility to it.<html></html>You set it up and register it to the configuration server in the Site Recovery portal.<html></html>
trans-unit.target: <html></html>Deploy as an on-premises virtual or physical server running Windows Server 2012 R2<html></html> <html></html>We recommend it's placed on the same network and LAN segment as the machines that you want to protect, but it can run on a different network as long as protected machines have L3 network visibility to it.<html></html>You set it up and register it to the configuration server in the Site Recovery portal.<html></html>

trans-unit.source: <html></html>Protected machines send replication data to the on-premises process server.It has a disk-based cache to cache replication data that it receives.It performs a number of actions on that data.<html></html><html></html>It optimizes data by caching, compressing, and encrypting it before sending it on to the master target server.<html></html><html></html>It handles push installation of the Mobility Service.<html></html><html></html>It performs automatic discovery of VMware virtual machines.<html></html>
trans-unit.target: <html></html>Protected machines send replication data to the on-premises process server.It has a disk-based cache to cache replication data that it receives.It performs a number of actions on that data.<html></html><html></html>It optimizes data by caching, compressing, and encrypting it before sending it on to the master target server.<html></html><html></html>It handles push installation of the Mobility Service.<html></html><html></html>It performs automatic discovery of VMware virtual machines.<html></html>

trans-unit.source: On-premises machines
trans-unit.target: On-premises machines

trans-unit.source: On-premises virtual machines running on a VMware hypervisor, or physical servers running Windows or Linux.
trans-unit.target: On-premises virtual machines running on a VMware hypervisor, or physical servers running Windows or Linux.

trans-unit.source: You set up replication settings that apply to virtual machines and servers.
trans-unit.target: You set up replication settings that apply to virtual machines and servers.

trans-unit.source: You can fail over an individual machine or more commonly, as part of a recovery plan containing multiple virtual machines that fail over together.
trans-unit.target: You can fail over an individual machine or more commonly, as part of a recovery plan containing multiple virtual machines that fail over together.

trans-unit.source: Mobility service
trans-unit.target: Mobility service

trans-unit.source: <html></html>Installs on each virtual machine or physical server you want to protect<html></html><html></html>Can be installed manually or pushed and installed automatically by the process server when protection is enabled for the server.
trans-unit.target: <html></html>Installs on each virtual machine or physical server you want to protect<html></html><html></html>Can be installed manually or pushed and installed automatically by the process server when protection is enabled for the server.

trans-unit.source: The Mobility service send data to the Process Server as part of initial replication (resync.)
trans-unit.target: The Mobility service send data to the Process Server as part of initial replication (resync.)

trans-unit.source: Once the server reaches a protected state(after resync is completed) the Mobility service performs an in-memory capture of writes to disk and sends it to the Process Server.
trans-unit.target: Once the server reaches a protected state(after resync is completed) the Mobility service performs an in-memory capture of writes to disk and sends it to the Process Server.

trans-unit.source: Application consistency for Windows servers is achieved using the VSS framework.
trans-unit.target: Application consistency for Windows servers is achieved using the VSS framework.

trans-unit.source: Azure Site Recovery vault
trans-unit.target: Azure Site Recovery vault

trans-unit.source: Set up after you've subscribed to the Site Recovery service.
trans-unit.target: Set up after you've subscribed to the Site Recovery service.

trans-unit.source: You register servers in a Site Recovery vault.
trans-unit.target: You register servers in a Site Recovery vault.

trans-unit.source: The vault coordinates and orchestrates data replication, failover, and recovery between your on-premises site and Azure.
trans-unit.target: The vault coordinates and orchestrates data replication, failover, and recovery between your on-premises site and Azure.

trans-unit.source: Replication mechanism
trans-unit.target: Replication mechanism

trans-unit.source: Over the Internet—Communicates and replicates data from protected on-premises servers and Azure using a secure SSL/TLS communication channel over a public internet connection. This is the default option.VPN/ExpressRoute—Communicates and replicates data between on-premises servers and Azure over a VPN connection. You'll need to set up a site-to-site VPN or an ExpressRoute connection between the on-premises site and your Azure network.You'll select how you want to replicate during Site Recovery deployment. You can't change the mechanism after it's configured without impacting protection on already protected servers.
trans-unit.target: Over the Internet—Communicates and replicates data from protected on-premises servers and Azure using a secure SSL/TLS communication channel over a public internet connection. This is the default option.VPN/ExpressRoute—Communicates and replicates data between on-premises servers and Azure over a VPN connection. You'll need to set up a site-to-site VPN or an ExpressRoute connection between the on-premises site and your Azure network.You'll select how you want to replicate during Site Recovery deployment. You can't change the mechanism after it's configured without impacting protection on already protected servers.

trans-unit.source: <html></html>Neither option requires you to open any inbound network ports on protected machines.All network communication is initiated from the on-premises site.<html></html>
trans-unit.target: <html></html>Neither option requires you to open any inbound network ports on protected machines.All network communication is initiated from the on-premises site.<html></html>

trans-unit.source: You can learn more about Site Recovery components, Providers and agents in <link><linkText>Site Recovery Components</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: You can learn more about Site Recovery components, Providers and agents in <link><linkText>Site Recovery Components</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Capacity planning
trans-unit.target: Capacity planning

trans-unit.source: Main areas for considerations are:
trans-unit.target: Main areas for considerations are:

trans-unit.source: Source environment—The VMware infrastructure, source machine settings and requirements.
trans-unit.target: Source environment—The VMware infrastructure, source machine settings and requirements.

trans-unit.source: Component servers—The process server, configuration server, and master target server
trans-unit.target: Component servers—The process server, configuration server, and master target server

trans-unit.source: Considerations for the source environment
trans-unit.target: Considerations for the source environment

trans-unit.source: Maximum disk size—The current maximum size of the disk that can be attached to a virtual machine is 1 TB.
trans-unit.target: Maximum disk size—The current maximum size of the disk that can be attached to a virtual machine is 1 TB.

trans-unit.source: Thus the maximum size of a source disk that can be replicated is also limited to 1 TB.
trans-unit.target: Thus the maximum size of a source disk that can be replicated is also limited to 1 TB.

trans-unit.source: Maximum size per source—The maximum size of a single source machine is 31 TB (with 31 disks) and with a D14 instance provisioned for the master target server.
trans-unit.target: Maximum size per source—The maximum size of a single source machine is 31 TB (with 31 disks) and with a D14 instance provisioned for the master target server.

trans-unit.source: Number of sources per master target server—Multiple source machines can be protected with a single master target server.
trans-unit.target: Number of sources per master target server—Multiple source machines can be protected with a single master target server.

trans-unit.source: However, a single source machine can’t be protected across multiple master target servers, because as disks replicate, a VHD that mirrors the size of the disk is created on Azure blob storage and attached as a data disk to the master target server.
trans-unit.target: However, a single source machine can’t be protected across multiple master target servers, because as disks replicate, a VHD that mirrors the size of the disk is created on Azure blob storage and attached as a data disk to the master target server.

trans-unit.source: Maximum daily change rate per source—There are three factors that need to be considered when considering the recommended change rate per source.
trans-unit.target: Maximum daily change rate per source—There are three factors that need to be considered when considering the recommended change rate per source.

trans-unit.source: For the target based considerations two IOPS are required on the target disk for each operation on the source.
trans-unit.target: For the target based considerations two IOPS are required on the target disk for each operation on the source.

trans-unit.source: This is because a read of old data and a write of the new data will happen on the target disk.
trans-unit.target: This is because a read of old data and a write of the new data will happen on the target disk.

trans-unit.source: Daily change rate supported by the process server—A source machine can't span multiple process servers.
trans-unit.target: Daily change rate supported by the process server—A source machine can't span multiple process servers.

trans-unit.source: A single process server can support up to 1 TB of daily change rate.
trans-unit.target: A single process server can support up to 1 TB of daily change rate.

trans-unit.source: Hence 1 TB is the maximum daily data change rate supported for a source machine.
trans-unit.target: Hence 1 TB is the maximum daily data change rate supported for a source machine.

trans-unit.source: Maximum throughput supported by the target disk—Maximum churn per source disk can't be more than 144 GB/day (with 8K write size).
trans-unit.target: Maximum throughput supported by the target disk—Maximum churn per source disk can't be more than 144 GB/day (with 8K write size).

trans-unit.source: See the table in the master target section for the throughput and IOPs of the target for various write sizes.
trans-unit.target: See the table in the master target section for the throughput and IOPs of the target for various write sizes.

trans-unit.source: This number must be divided by two because each source IOP generates 2 IOPS on the target disk.
trans-unit.target: This number must be divided by two because each source IOP generates 2 IOPS on the target disk.

trans-unit.source: Refer <link><linkText>Scalability and Performance Targets when using Premium Storage</linkText><title></title></link> while configuring target for Premium Storage account.
trans-unit.target: Refer <link><linkText>Scalability and Performance Targets when using Premium Storage</linkText><title></title></link> while configuring target for Premium Storage account.

trans-unit.source: Maximum throughput supported by the storage account—A source can't span multiple storage accounts.
trans-unit.target: Maximum throughput supported by the storage account—A source can't span multiple storage accounts.

trans-unit.source: Given that a storage account takes a maximum of 20,000 requests per second and that each source IOP generates 2 IOPS at the master target server, we recommend you keep the number of IOPS across the source to 10,000.
trans-unit.target: Given that a storage account takes a maximum of 20,000 requests per second and that each source IOP generates 2 IOPS at the master target server, we recommend you keep the number of IOPS across the source to 10,000.

trans-unit.source: Refer <link><linkText>Scalability and Performance Targets when using Premium Storage</linkText><title></title></link> while configuring source for Premium Storage account.
trans-unit.target: Refer <link><linkText>Scalability and Performance Targets when using Premium Storage</linkText><title></title></link> while configuring source for Premium Storage account.

trans-unit.source: Process server considerations
trans-unit.target: Process server considerations

trans-unit.source: Generally process server sizing depends on the daily change rate across all protected workloads.
trans-unit.target: Generally process server sizing depends on the daily change rate across all protected workloads.

trans-unit.source: Primary considerations include:
trans-unit.target: Primary considerations include:

trans-unit.source: You need sufficient compute to perform tasks such as inline compression and encryption.
trans-unit.target: You need sufficient compute to perform tasks such as inline compression and encryption.

trans-unit.source: Process server uses disk based cache.
trans-unit.target: Process server uses disk based cache.

trans-unit.source: Make sure the recommended cache space and disk throughput is available to facilitate the data changes stored in the event of network bottleneck or outage.
trans-unit.target: Make sure the recommended cache space and disk throughput is available to facilitate the data changes stored in the event of network bottleneck or outage.

trans-unit.source: Ensure sufficient bandwidth so that the process server can upload the data to the master target server to provide continuous data protection.
trans-unit.target: Ensure sufficient bandwidth so that the process server can upload the data to the master target server to provide continuous data protection.

trans-unit.target: Daily change rate

trans-unit.source: Retention volume storage.
trans-unit.target: Retention volume storage.

trans-unit.source: Note that:
trans-unit.target: Note that:

trans-unit.source: One source can't span multiple storage accounts.
trans-unit.target: One source can't span multiple storage accounts.

trans-unit.source: This applies to the data disk that go to the storage accounts selected when you configure protection.
trans-unit.target: This applies to the data disk that go to the storage accounts selected when you configure protection.

trans-unit.source: The OS and the retention disks usually go to the automatically deployed storage account.
trans-unit.target: The OS and the retention disks usually go to the automatically deployed storage account.

trans-unit.source: The retention storage volume required depends on the daily change rate and the number of retention days.
trans-unit.target: The retention storage volume required depends on the daily change rate and the number of retention days.

trans-unit.source: The retention storage required per master target server = total churn from source per day * number of retention days.
trans-unit.target: The retention storage required per master target server = total churn from source per day * number of retention days.

trans-unit.source: Each master target server has only one retention volume.
trans-unit.target: Each master target server has only one retention volume.

trans-unit.source: The retention volume is shared across the disks attached to the master target server.
trans-unit.target: The retention volume is shared across the disks attached to the master target server.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: If there's a source machine with 5 disks and each disk generates 120 IOPS (8K size) on the source, this translates to 240 IOPS per disk (2 operations on the target disk per source IO).
trans-unit.target: If there's a source machine with 5 disks and each disk generates 120 IOPS (8K size) on the source, this translates to 240 IOPS per disk (2 operations on the target disk per source IO).

trans-unit.source: 240 IOPS is within the Azure per disk IOPS limit of 500.
trans-unit.target: 240 IOPS is within the Azure per disk IOPS limit of 500.

trans-unit.source: On the retention volume, this becomes 120 * 5 = 600 IOPS and this can become a bottle neck.
trans-unit.target: On the retention volume, this becomes 120 * 5 = 600 IOPS and this can become a bottle neck.

trans-unit.source: In this scenario, a good strategy would be to add more disks to the retention volume and span it across, as a RAID stripe configuration.
trans-unit.target: In this scenario, a good strategy would be to add more disks to the retention volume and span it across, as a RAID stripe configuration.

trans-unit.source: This will improve performance because the IOPS are distributed across multiple drives.
trans-unit.target: This will improve performance because the IOPS are distributed across multiple drives.

trans-unit.source: The number of drives to be added to the retention volume will be as follows:
trans-unit.target: The number of drives to be added to the retention volume will be as follows:

trans-unit.source: - Total IOPS from source environment / 500
trans-unit.target: - Total IOPS from source environment / 500

trans-unit.source: - Total churn per day from source environment (uncompressed) / 287 GB. 287 GB is the maximum throughput supported by a target disk per day.
trans-unit.target: - Total churn per day from source environment (uncompressed) / 287 GB. 287 GB is the maximum throughput supported by a target disk per day.

trans-unit.source: This metric will vary based on the write size with a factor of 8K, because in this case 8K is thee assumed write size.
trans-unit.target: This metric will vary based on the write size with a factor of 8K, because in this case 8K is thee assumed write size.

trans-unit.source: For example, if the write size is 4K then throughput will be 287/2.
trans-unit.target: For example, if the write size is 4K then throughput will be 287/2.

trans-unit.source: And if the write size is 16K then throughput will be 287*2.
trans-unit.target: And if the write size is 16K then throughput will be 287*2.

trans-unit.source: The number of storage accounts required = total source IOPs/10000.
trans-unit.target: The number of storage accounts required = total source IOPs/10000.

trans-unit.target: You'll need an Azure virtual network on which the configuration server and master target server will be deployed.

trans-unit.target: It should be in the same subscription and region as the Azure Site Recovery vault.

trans-unit.source: Azure virtual machines
trans-unit.target: Azure virtual machines

trans-unit.source: Virtual machines you want to protect should conform with Azure prerequisites.Disk count—A maximum of 31 disks can be supported on a single protected serverDisk sizes—Individual disk capacity shouldn't be more than 1023 GBClustering—Clustered servers aren't supportedBoot—Unified Extensible Firmware Interface(UEFI)/Extensible Firmware Interface(EFI) boot isn't supportedVolumes—Bitlocker encrypted volumes aren't supported Server names—Names should contain between 1 and 63 characters (letters, numbers and hyphens).The name must start with a letter or number and end with a letter or number.After a machine is protected you can modify the Azure name.
trans-unit.target: Virtual machines you want to protect should conform with Azure prerequisites.Disk count—A maximum of 31 disks can be supported on a single protected serverDisk sizes—Individual disk capacity shouldn't be more than 1023 GBClustering—Clustered servers aren't supportedBoot—Unified Extensible Firmware Interface(UEFI)/Extensible Firmware Interface(EFI) boot isn't supportedVolumes—Bitlocker encrypted volumes aren't supported Server names—Names should contain between 1 and 63 characters (letters, numbers and hyphens).The name must start with a letter or number and end with a letter or number.After a machine is protected you can modify the Azure name.

trans-unit.target: Configuration server

trans-unit.source: <html></html>Standard A3 virtual machine based on an Azure Site Recovery Windows Server 2012 R2 gallery image will be created in your subscription for the configuration server.It's created as the first instance in a new cloud service.If you select Public Internet as the connectivity type for the Configuration Server the cloud service will be created with a reserved public IP address.<html></html><html></html>The installation path should be in English characters only.<html></html>
trans-unit.target: <html></html>Standard A3 virtual machine based on an Azure Site Recovery Windows Server 2012 R2 gallery image will be created in your subscription for the configuration server.It's created as the first instance in a new cloud service.If you select Public Internet as the connectivity type for the Configuration Server the cloud service will be created with a reserved public IP address.<html></html><html></html>The installation path should be in English characters only.<html></html>

trans-unit.source: Master target server
trans-unit.target: Master target server

trans-unit.source: Azure virtual machine, standard A4, D14 or DS4.The installation path should be in English characters only. For example the path should be /usr/local/ASR for a master target server running Linux.
trans-unit.target: Azure virtual machine, standard A4, D14 or DS4.The installation path should be in English characters only. For example the path should be /usr/local/ASR for a master target server running Linux.

trans-unit.source: Process server
trans-unit.target: Process server

trans-unit.source: <html></html>You can deploy the process server on physical or virtual machine running Windows Server 2012 R2 with the latest updates.Install on C:/.<html></html><html></html>We recommend you place the server on the same network and subnet as the machines you want to protect.<html></html><html></html>Install VMware vSphere CLI 5.5.0 on the process server.The VMware vSphere CLI component is required on the process server in order to discover virtual machines managed by a vCenter server or virtual machines running on an ESXi host.<html></html><html></html>The installation path should be in English characters only.<html></html>
trans-unit.target: <html></html>You can deploy the process server on physical or virtual machine running Windows Server 2012 R2 with the latest updates.Install on C:/.<html></html><html></html>We recommend you place the server on the same network and subnet as the machines you want to protect.<html></html><html></html>Install VMware vSphere CLI 5.5.0 on the process server.The VMware vSphere CLI component is required on the process server in order to discover virtual machines managed by a vCenter server or virtual machines running on an ESXi host.<html></html><html></html>The installation path should be in English characters only.<html></html>

trans-unit.source: VMware
trans-unit.target: VMware

trans-unit.source: <html></html>A VMware vCenter server managing your VMware vSphere hypervisors.It should be running vCenter version 5.1 or 5.5 with the latest updates.<html></html><html></html>One or more vSphere hypervisors containing VMware virtual machines you want to protect.The hypervisor should be running ESX/ESXi version 5.1 or 5.5 with the latest updates.<html></html><html></html>VMware virtual machines should have VMware tools installed and running.<html></html>
trans-unit.target: <html></html>A VMware vCenter server managing your VMware vSphere hypervisors.It should be running vCenter version 5.1 or 5.5 with the latest updates.<html></html><html></html>One or more vSphere hypervisors containing VMware virtual machines you want to protect.The hypervisor should be running ESX/ESXi version 5.1 or 5.5 with the latest updates.<html></html><html></html>VMware virtual machines should have VMware tools installed and running.<html></html>

trans-unit.source: Windows machines
trans-unit.target: Windows machines

trans-unit.source: Protected physical servers or VMware virtual machines running Windows have a number of requirements.A supported 64-bit operating system: Windows Server 2012 R2, Windows Server 2012, or Windows Server 2008 R2 with at least SP1.The host name, mount points, device names, Windows system path (eg: C:\Windows) should be in English only.The operating system should be installed on C:\ drive.Only basic disks are supported. Dynamic disks aren't supported.You'll need to provide an administrator account (must be a local administrator on the Windows machine) to push install the Mobility Service on Windows servers. If the provided account is a non-domain account you'll need to disable Remote User Access control on the local machine. To do this add the LocalAccountTokenFilterPolicy DWORD registry entry with a value of 1 under HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies\System. To add the registry entry from a CLI open cmd or powershell and enter **REG ADD HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies\System /v LocalAccountTokenFilterPolicy /t REG_DWORD /d 1**. Learn more about access control.After failover, if you want connect to Windows virtual machines in Azure with Remote Desktop make sure that Remote Desktop is enabled for the on-premises machine. If you're not connecting over VPN, firewall rules should allow Remote Desktop connections over the internet.
trans-unit.target: Protected physical servers or VMware virtual machines running Windows have a number of requirements.A supported 64-bit operating system: Windows Server 2012 R2, Windows Server 2012, or Windows Server 2008 R2 with at least SP1.The host name, mount points, device names, Windows system path (eg: C:\Windows) should be in English only.The operating system should be installed on C:\ drive.Only basic disks are supported. Dynamic disks aren't supported.You'll need to provide an administrator account (must be a local administrator on the Windows machine) to push install the Mobility Service on Windows servers. If the provided account is a non-domain account you'll need to disable Remote User Access control on the local machine. To do this add the LocalAccountTokenFilterPolicy DWORD registry entry with a value of 1 under HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies\System. To add the registry entry from a CLI open cmd or powershell and enter **REG ADD HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies\System /v LocalAccountTokenFilterPolicy /t REG_DWORD /d 1**. Learn more about access control.After failover, if you want connect to Windows virtual machines in Azure with Remote Desktop make sure that Remote Desktop is enabled for the on-premises machine. If you're not connecting over VPN, firewall rules should allow Remote Desktop connections over the internet.

trans-unit.source: Linux machines
trans-unit.target: Linux machines

trans-unit.source: A supported 64 bit operating system: Centos 6.4, 6.5, 6.6; Oracle Enterprise Linux 6.4, 6.5 running either the Red Hat compatible kernel or Unbreakable Enterprise Kernel Release 3 (UEK3), SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 11 SP3.Firewall rules on protected machines should allow them to reach the configuration and master target servers in Azure./etc/hosts files on protected machines should contain entries that map the local host name to IP addresses associated with all NICs If you want to connect to an Azure virtual machine running Linux after failover using a Secure Shell client (ssh), ensure that the Secure Shell service on the protected machine is set to start automatically on system boot, and that firewall rules allow an ssh connection to it.The host name, mount points, device names, and Linux system paths and file names (eg /etc/; /usr) should be in English only.Protection can be enabled for on-premises machines with the following storage:-File system: EXT3, ETX4, ReiserFS, XFSMultipath software-Device Mapper (multipath)Volume manager: LVM2Physical servers with HP CCISS controller storage are not supported.
trans-unit.target: A supported 64 bit operating system: Centos 6.4, 6.5, 6.6; Oracle Enterprise Linux 6.4, 6.5 running either the Red Hat compatible kernel or Unbreakable Enterprise Kernel Release 3 (UEK3), SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 11 SP3.Firewall rules on protected machines should allow them to reach the configuration and master target servers in Azure./etc/hosts files on protected machines should contain entries that map the local host name to IP addresses associated with all NICs If you want to connect to an Azure virtual machine running Linux after failover using a Secure Shell client (ssh), ensure that the Secure Shell service on the protected machine is set to start automatically on system boot, and that firewall rules allow an ssh connection to it.The host name, mount points, device names, and Linux system paths and file names (eg /etc/; /usr) should be in English only.Protection can be enabled for on-premises machines with the following storage:-File system: EXT3, ETX4, ReiserFS, XFSMultipath software-Device Mapper (multipath)Volume manager: LVM2Physical servers with HP CCISS controller storage are not supported.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Deployment steps</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Network connectivity Type
trans-unit.target: Network connectivity Type

trans-unit.source: You have two options to configure network connectivity between your on-premises site and the Azure virtual network on which your Infrastructure components (Configuration Server, Master target Servers) are deployed.
trans-unit.target: You have two options to configure network connectivity between your on-premises site and the Azure virtual network on which your Infrastructure components (Configuration Server, Master target Servers) are deployed.

trans-unit.source: You'll need to decide which network connectivity option to use before you can deploy your Configuration Server.
trans-unit.target: You'll need to decide which network connectivity option to use before you can deploy your Configuration Server.

trans-unit.source: This is a deployment time choice, and cannot be changed later.
trans-unit.target: This is a deployment time choice, and cannot be changed later.

trans-unit.source: Public Internet : Communication and replication of data between the on-premises servers (Process Server, Protected Servers) and the Azure Infrastructure component servers (Configuration Server, Master Target Server) happens over a secure SSL/TLS connection from on-premises to the Public endpoints on the Configuration Server and the Master Target server.
trans-unit.target: Public Internet : Communication and replication of data between the on-premises servers (Process Server, Protected Servers) and the Azure Infrastructure component servers (Configuration Server, Master Target Server) happens over a secure SSL/TLS connection from on-premises to the Public endpoints on the Configuration Server and the Master Target server.

trans-unit.source: (The only exception is the connection between the Process Server and the Master Target server on TCP port 9080 which is un-encrypted.
trans-unit.target: (The only exception is the connection between the Process Server and the Master Target server on TCP port 9080 which is un-encrypted.

trans-unit.source: Only control information related to the replication protocol related used to setup the replication is exchanged on this connection.)
trans-unit.target: Only control information related to the replication protocol related used to setup the replication is exchanged on this connection.)

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Deployment diagram internet</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Deployment diagram internet</linkText>

trans-unit.source: VPN : Communication and replication of data between the on-premises servers (Process Server, Protected Servers) and the Azure Infrastructure component servers (Configuration Server, Master Target Server) happens over a VPN connection between your on-premises network and the Azure virtual network on which the Configuration server and Master Target servers are deployed.
trans-unit.target: VPN : Communication and replication of data between the on-premises servers (Process Server, Protected Servers) and the Azure Infrastructure component servers (Configuration Server, Master Target Server) happens over a VPN connection between your on-premises network and the Azure virtual network on which the Configuration server and Master Target servers are deployed.

trans-unit.source: Ensure that your on-premises network is connected to the Azure virtual network by an ExpressRoute connection or a site-to-site VPN connection.
trans-unit.target: Ensure that your on-premises network is connected to the Azure virtual network by an ExpressRoute connection or a site-to-site VPN connection.
